chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The Telepathy framework allows applications to use real-time communications via several common protocols, such as XMPP (Jabber). For instance, an instant messenger application might use Telepathy to allow chats with online contacts via accounts with various IM services. Or a game might use Telepathy to simplify the implementation of its networking code, allowing users to play against each other.
Telepathy is a D-Bus API so it may be used from most programming languages.
All this functionality is available under an open source license, allowing people to make improvements and add new features.

chapter.title: Basics
chapter.para: This chapter introduces some basic techniques and concepts that you must understand to use Telepathy confidently. You should read through this chapter before proceeding, but you will probably want to refer back here again later.

sect1.title: Using D-Bus
sect1.para: Telepathy is a D-Bus API. Telepathy components conform to the Telepathy D-Bus Specification, which is therefore also the main Telepathy API reference.

D-Bus is an IPC (Inter-process communication) system, allowing different software components to be implemented in different processes, with different programming languages. It also allows multiple applications to easily share functionality from a single process. Most examples in this book will use language bindings instead of using D-Bus directly. However, an understanding of the following D-Bus concepts will help you even when using language bindings.

listitem.para: A process can make a service available by connecting to a D-Bus bus and requesting a "well-known" bus name for the connection, such as "com.mycompany.TextEditor", by which other processes, such as applications, can access it.
The service process provides D-Bus objects on that bus name. Each object has an object path, such as "/com/company/TextEditor", which a client application must specify to use that object.

Each D-Bus object implements one or more D-Bus interfaces. Each interface has an interface name, such as "com.mycompany.TextEditor". Each interface provides one or more methods or signals, each with a member name.

sect1.para: Of course, for simple services with just one object that provides just one interface, these three names will often look very similar.

In the following sections you will see how a D-Bus API can be used from some common programming languages. In these examples, we use the FreeDesktop Notification system, which should be available on most modern Linux installations. The examples should cause a message to popup from your desktop panel. Note that, like Telepathy, this service is available on the Session Bus rather than the System Bus. Services on the Session Bus are for the current user's session only. Services on the System Bus are shared between all users.

These programming languages allow you to call D-Bus methods synchronously, meaning that they block until they can return the method's result. However, that is generally disapproved of because the D-Bus service may take a long time to reply, and because of some fundamental technical problems with the use of blocking calls between processes. Therefore, the examples call the D-Bus method asynchronously, theoretically allowing the application to continue with other tasks while waiting for the result.

sect2.title: Using D-Bus from C, with glib
sect2.para: This example uses dbus-glib's dbus_g_proxy_begin_call() function to call the Notify() method on the org.freedesktop.Notification interface of the desktop notification service at the /org/freedesktop/Notification path. Note that we must specify the types of each parameter.
We could have used the synchronous dbus_g_proxy_call() function instead but, as already mentioned, asynchronous calls are generally preferred with D-Bus.

sect1.title: Language Bindings
sect1.para: As mentioned in the Using D-Bus section, many programming languages have their own generic ways of using D-Bus APIs. In addition, there are some Telepathy-specific APIs to make the use of Telepathy even easier. For instance, telepathy-glib provides an API that is familiar to users of Glib and GTK+, using the GObject system and related conventions.
Likewise, the Telepathy-Qt project provides a more Qt-like API for Telepathy and Telepathy-Python does the same for Python.

sect2.para: The C examples in this book will use telepathy-glib.

sect1.title: Connection Managers
sect1.para: Support for the various communication protocols is provided by various Connection Managers. For instance, the telepathy-gabble Connection Manager provides support for the XMPP protocol, also known as Jabber.

There is no central &app; D-Bus service. Instead there are several connection manager services, activated on demand, and each of these connection managers provide the same core set of D-Bus interfaces, such as Connection and Channel, allowing application code to be written generically for all connection managers.

sect1.title: Optional Interfaces
sect1.para: Although a core set of D-Bus interfaces is provided by all connection managers, some extra D-Bus interfaces are optional. For instance, some connection managers only provide extra interfaces when it discovers that the remote server provides that optional functionality. Therefore, when using these interfaces, application code should first check that the interface is available, sometimes falling back to alternative interfaces. Use the Connection interface's GetInterfaces() method for this.

note.para: Note that the Connection.GetInterfaces() method does more than the standard D-Bus Introspectable.Introspect() method. GetInterfaces() allows tools and language bindings to know about the possible availability of interfaces via Introspect() while providing an additional check that the interface is really supported for the particular connection manager with the particular remote server to which that connection manager is connected.

chapter.title: Connection
chapter.para: TODO: Notes: - This is my connection to my IM account. - A connection has Channels. - Connection gives me several ContactList Channels (subscribe, publish, etc) - Provides a Group interface. - Contains many members (Contact handles). Note that there is no Contact interface or object (just a handle), for performance reasons. - Has several optional interfaces (Avatars, Presence, etc). - And some optional interfaces that just improve similar existing interfaces, such as Connection.Interface.Requests instead of Connection.RequestChannel - Provides a SimplePresence interface, to which I can give a contact handle to discover if that contact is online. The SimplePresence interface emits signals when contacts' presence changes. (SimplePresence replaces the Presence interface, to be deprecated soon.) - Similarly, the Avatars and Aliasing interfaces on the Connection provide other information about contacts, and notifications when they change. - (Having interfaces on the connection rather than the contacts makes overall contact handling easier.) - Has a RequestChannel() method that takes a channel type (text/voip/tubes) and a handle (contact, room, list or group) handle. - A new ContactCapabilities interface will allow retrieving of multiple types of information at once (string of handle, alias, avatar, presence, etc), which is more efficient.
